front.title: JSCalendar: Converting from and to iCalendar

section.name: Notational Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCPÂ 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.
The ABNF definitions in this document use the notations of . ABNF rules not defined in this document either are defined in or .

section.name: Example Notations
section.t: This document contains examples that illustrate how to convert between the iCalendar and JSCalendar data formats. The notation of these examples is such that their main points should be clear to the reader, but their contents can also be parsed for automated testing. The authors of this document implemented a tool that extracts these examples for interoperation testing. The following sections define the notation for such examples.

section.name: iCalendar Examples
section.t: An iCalendar example contains either an extract or a complete representation of iCalendar data. It always represents an iCalendar object, even if the example only depicts non-VCALENDAR components or properties.

An example that only contains iCalendar properties implicitly represents a VEVENT component that is part of a VCALENDAR component. An example that only contains one or more non-VCALENDAR components implicitly represents a VCALENDAR component that contains them. Implicit components are assumed to contain mandatory properties with some value, but the actual value is irrevelant for the main point of the example.

To illustrate this, , contains three examples, all of which represent the same iCalendar data. In the first example, both the VEVENT component and VCALENDAR component are implicit, including their mandatory properties. In the second example, only the VCALENDAR component and its mandatory properties are implicit. The third example depicts a complete VCALENDAR component, nothing is implicit.

figure.name: Examples for implicit and explicit iCalendar component notation
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTAMP:20060102T030405Z DTSTART:20060102T030405Z SUMMARY:hello UID:CC0A494A-6E07-4827-8294-0752DD1ECFA4 END:VEVENT
BEGIN:VCALENDAR PRODID:-//FOO//bar//EN VERSION:2.0 BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTAMP:20060102T030405Z DTSTART:20060102T030405Z SUMMARY:hello UID:CC0A494A-6E07-4827-8294-0752DD1ECFA4 END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.t: A line containing just the value ... stands for any other properties that might be present in a component but are irrevelant for this example. This includes mandatory properties. illustrates this as an alternative representation for the examples of .

figure.name: Example for additional properties represented by ...

section.t: A line starting with two spaces represents the continuation of a folded content line (). illustrates this.

figure.name: Example for a folded content line

section.name: JSCalendar Examples
section.t: A JSCalendar example always represents a Group object, even if the example only depicts one of the Group entries or properties.

JSCalendar objects are depicted either explicitly or implicitly. An explicit JSCalendar object starts and ends with braces. An implicit JSCalendar object omits braces, it only consists of JSON name/value pairs, separated by comma.

An implicit JSCalendar object is assumed to be of type Event, unless it contains the @type property with a different value. It is assumed to contain mandatory properties with some value, but the actual value is irrevelant for the main point of the example.

illustrates this with multiple examples, all of which represent the same JSCalendar data. The first example contains an implicit JSCalendar object of type Event. The second example contains an implicit JSCalendar object with a @type property. The third example contains an explicit Event object but the Group object containing it is omitted. The fourth example contains the full Group object, nothing is omitted.

figure.name: Examples for implicit and explicit JSCalendar object notation

section.t: A property with name "..." and value "" stands for additional properties that might be present in a JSCalendar object, but which are irrelevant for this example. This includes mandatory properties. illustrates this as an alternative representation for the examples of .

figure.name: Example for additional properties represented by ...

section.name: Generating JSCalendar Ids
section.t: In many places in JSCalendar, a JSON map is used where the map keys are of type Id (. If an iCalendar property or component converts to a value in these JSON maps, then an implementation needs to choose an identifier as key.

This document defines the new JSID parameter and JSID property, which allow to set a JSCalendar Id value when converting from JSCalendar to iCalendar. If they are set on a property or the component, then its value MUST be used a map key when converting from iCalendar to JSCalendar. If no such parameter or property is set, then an implementation is free to choose any identifier as map key, as long the following requirements are met:

ul.li: The identifier MUST be a valid Id value.
If the same iCalendar object is converted twice, then the identifier for each property or component MUST stay the same, irrespective of the order in which properties and subcomponents are processed.

section.t: In a few cases, an iCalendar property and component may both convert to the same JSCalendar object. Examples for this are the ATTENDEE property and PARTICIPANT component, as well as the LOCATION property and VLOCATION component ...TBD

section.name: iCalendar Objects
section.t: An iCalendar object () converts to a JSCalendar object of type Group ().

figure.name: Example for converting an iCalendar object

section.t: Converting an iCalendar stream of multiple iCalendar objects is is implementation-specific, as multiple protocols and applications may have differing requirements.

section.name: BINARY
section.t: The BINARY value data type converts to a JSON string having as value an URI in the data URL scheme .
The data URL SHOULD use Base64-encoding, but it MAY use any other encoding that is valid according to .

figure.name: Example for converting a BINARY value to JSCalendar

section.name: BOOLEAN
section.t: The BOOLEAN value data type converts to the JSON literal names "true" and "false" by lowercasing the BOOLEAN value.

figure.name: Example for converting the BOOLEAN value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: CAL-ADDRESS
section.t: The CAL-ADDRESS value data type converts to a JSON string having the same value as the CAL-ADDRESS.

figure.name: Example for converting the CAL-ADDRESS value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: DATE
section.t: The DATE value data type converts to the LocalDateTime type . The year, month and day of month values convert as-is. The hour, minute and second values are all zero, fractional seconds are omitted.
Whether to interpret the resulting value as a timeless temporal or a temporal having zero time is specific to the JSCalendar property or object definition.

figure.name: Example for converting the DATE value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: DATE-TIME
section.t: The DATE-TIME value data type in form "DATE WITH LOCAL TIME" converts to the LocalDateTime type, the DATE-TIME in form "DATE WITH UTC TIME" to the UTCDateTime type.
The year, month, day of month, hour, minute and second values convert as-is, fractional seconds are omitted.
Some properties define different conversion rules for DATE-TIME values, for example the DTSTART and RECURRENCE-ID properties.

figure.name: Example for converting a "DATE WITH LOCAL TIME" DATE-TIME value data type to JSCalendar
Example for converting a "DATE WITH UTC TIME" DATE-TIME value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: DURATION
section.t: The DURATION value data type converts to the Duration type . The DURATION value converts as-is, fractional seconds are omitted.

figure.name: Example for converting the DURATION value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: FLOAT
section.t: The FLOAT value data type does not convert to any JSCalendar value type.
defines how to convert the GEO property value. defines how to convert arbitrary iCalendar properties and types.

section.name: INTEGER
section.t: The INTEGER value data type converts to either the Int type or the UnsignedInt type, depending on the value type of the JSCalendar property.

figure.name: Example for converting the INTEGER value data type to the JSCalendar Int type
Example for converting the INTEGER value data type to the JSCalendar UnsignedInt type

section.name: PERIOD
section.t: The PERIOD value data type does not convert to any JSCalendar value type.
defines how to convert arbitrary iCalendar properties and types.

section.name: RECUR
section.t: The RECUR value data type converts to the RecurrenceRule type as follows:

The string values of the FREQ, WKST, RSCALE convert to lowercase. The UTC date-time value of the UNTIL part converts to a LocalDateTime value in the timezone of the JSCalendar Event's or Task's timeZone property, or floating time. The entries in the numeric list properties such as byHour MUST be deduplicated and sorted ascending.

figure.name: Example for converting the RECUR value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: TEXT
section.t: The TEXT value data type( converts to a JSON string. Any escaped character in the iCalendar TEXT value MUST be unescaped during conversion, any line folds MUST be ignored.

figure.name: Example for converting the TEXT value data type to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: DESCRIPTION:Lorem ipsum odor amet\,\nconsectetuer adipiscing elit.

section.name: TIME
section.t: The TIME value data type does not convert to any JSCalendar value type.
defines how to convert arbitrary iCalendar properties and types.

section.name: UID
section.t: The UID value data type converts a JSON string. Any escaped character in the iCalendar UID value MUST be unescaped during conversion, any line folds MUST be ignored.

figure.name: Example for converting the UID value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: UNKNOWN
section.t: The UNKNOWN value data type is reserved. It does not convert to any JSCalendar value type.
defines how to convert arbitrary iCalendar properties and types.

section.name: URI
section.t: The URI value data type converts a JSON string. The string value MUST be valid according to the syntax rules defined in and updates.

figure.name: Example for converting the URI value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: UTC-OFFSET
section.t: The UTC-OFFSET value data type converts to a JSON string.
See and for examples.

section.name: XML-REFERENCE
section.t: The XML-REFERENCE value data type converts to a JSON string. The same conversion rules as for the URI type apply.

figure.name: Example for converting the XML-REFERENCE value data type to JSCalendar

section.name: AVAILABLE
section.t: The AVAILABLE component does not convert to a standard JSCalendar object.

section.name: DAYLIGHT
section.t: The DAYLIGHT component converts to a TimeZoneRule object in the daylight property of a TimeZone object.

figure.name: Example for converting the DAYLIGHT component to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR ... BEGIN:VTIMEZONE TZID:NonIana BEGIN:DAYLIGHT TZOFFSETFROM:-0400 TZOFFSETTO:-0300 DTSTART:20010503T000000 END:DAYLIGHT END:VTIMEZONE ... BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTART;TZID=NonIana:20241004T010000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: PARTICIPANT
section.t: The PARTICIPANT component converts to a Participant object in the participants property.

figure.name: Example for converting the PARTICIPANT component to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT ... BEGIN:PARTICIPANT UID:47AD2E1C-49D4-45DF-BD83-8398ACC7D8E2 STRUCTURED-DATA;VALUE=URI: http://dir.example.com/vcard/contacts/contact1.vcf PARTICIPANT-TYPE:CONTACT DESCRIPTION:A contact END:PARTICIPANT END:VEVENT

section.name: Converting a schedulable PARTICIPANT component
section.t: defines a PARTICIPANT component to be schedulable if it has a CALENDAR-ADDRESS property set and the value of that property matches the value of an ATTENDEE property in the enclosing component.
In this case, both the PARTICIPANT component and the ATTENDEE property convert to the same Participant object in the participants property.

figure.name: Example for converting the PARTICIPANT component to JSCalendar

section.name: STANDARD
section.t: The STANDARD component converts to a TimeZoneRule object in the standard property of a TimeZone object.

figure.name: Example for converting the STANDARD component to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR ... BEGIN:VTIMEZONE TZID:NonIana BEGIN:STANDARD TZOFFSETFROM:-0400 TZOFFSETTO:-0300 DTSTART:20010503T000000 END:STANDARD END:VTIMEZONE ... BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTART;TZID=NonIana:20241004T010000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: VALARM
section.t: The VALARM component converts to an Alert object in the alerts property.

figure.name: Example for converting the VALARM component to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT ... BEGIN:VALARM TRIGGER:-PT30M ACTION:DISPLAY DESCRIPTION:Breakfast meeting END:VALARM END:VEVENT

section.name: VAVAILABILITY
section.t: The VAVAILABILITY component does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: VCALENDAR
section.t: See .

section.name: VEVENT
section.t: The VEVENT component converts an Event object

figure.name: Example for converting the VEVENT component to JSCalendar

section.name: Converting VEVENT components with differing UID values
section.t: VEVENT components having differing UID property values convert to different entries in the Group. They sort in the same order as in the VCALENDAR component.

figure.name: Example for converting VEVENT components with differing UID property values to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:DE935D01-3DF7-4201-B61A-D77D05C8B21A ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:60BE3D6E-6383-473A-BCF1-3C43EA1FA571 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: VEVENT recurrence overrides
section.t: VEVENT components having equal UID property values and all but one of them having the RECURRENCE-ID property set, convert to a single Event object. The VEVENT component without a RECURRENCE-ID property converts to the Event object, all other VEVENT components with that UID value convert to a recurrence override of that event.

figure.name: Example for converting VEVENT components as recurrence overrides to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RRULE:FREQ=DAILY DTSTART:20240101T140000 ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID:20240202T140000 DTSTART:20240202T160000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: VEVENT recurrence instances
section.t: VEVENT components having equal UID property values and all of them having a RECURRENCE-ID property set, convert to multiple Event objects. Each Event MUST have the recurrenceId property set, as well as the recurrenceIdTimeZone property if not null. They sort in the same order as in the VCALENDAR component.

figure.name: Example for converting VEVENT components as stand-alone recurrence instances to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID:20240202T140000 DTSTART:20240202T160000 ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID:20240103T140000 DTSTART:20240103T140000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: VFREEBUSY
section.t: The VFREEBUSY component does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: VJOURNAL
section.t: The VJOURNAL component does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: VLOCATION
section.t: The VLOCATION component converts to a Location object in the locations property.

figure.name: Example for converting the VLOCATION component to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT ... BEGIN:VLOCATION UID:123456-abcdef-98765432 NAME:The venue STRUCTURED-DATA;VALUE=URI: http://dir.example.com/venues/big-hall.vcf END:VLOCATION END:VEVENT

section.name: VRESOURCE
section.t: The VRESOURCE component converts to a Participant object in the participants property. The Participant kind property value MUST be set to "resource".

figure.name: Example for converting the VRESOURCE component to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT ... BEGIN:VRESOURCE UID:456789-abcdef-98765432 NAME:The projector RESOURCE-TYPE:projector STRUCTURED-DATA;VALUE=URI:http://dir.example.com/projectors/3d.vcf END:VRESOURCE END:VEVENT

section.name: VTIMEZONE
section.t: The VTIMEZONE component converts to a TimeZone object in the timeZones property of a Group, Event or Task object.

figure.name: Example for converting the VTIMEZONE component to JSCalendar
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR ... BEGIN:VTIMEZONE TZID:Puerto_Rico LAST-MODIFIED:20240909T122233Z BEGIN:DAYLIGHT TZNAME:AWT TZOFFSETFROM:-0400 TZOFFSETTO:-0300 DTSTART:19420503T000000 END:DAYLIGHT BEGIN:DAYLIGHT TZNAME:APT TZOFFSETFROM:-0300 TZOFFSETTO:-0300 DTSTART:19450814T200000 END:DAYLIGHT BEGIN:STANDARD TZNAME:AST TZOFFSETFROM:-0300 TZOFFSETTO:-0400 DTSTART:19450930T020000 END:STANDARD END:VTIMEZONE BEGIN:VEVENT ... DTSTART;TZID=Puerto_Rico:20080708T130000 END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: VTODO
section.t: The VTODO component converts to a Task object.
If a VCALENDAR component contains multiple VTODOs then the same rules as defined for VEVENT apply ( ff.).

figure.name: Example for converting the VTODO component to JSCalendar

section.name: ACKNOWLEDGED
section.t: The ACKNOWLEDGED property converts to the acknowledged property of an Alert object.

figure.name: Example for converting the ACKNOWLEDGED property to JSCalendar

section.name: ACTION
section.t: The ACTION property converts to the action property of an Alert object.

figure.name: Example for converting the ACTION property to JSCalendar

section.name: ATTACH
section.t: The ATTACH property converts to a Link object in the links property of an Event, Group or Task object, or Location object, or Participant object. Its value converts to that Link object's href property.

figure.name: Example for converting the ATTACH property to JSCalendar

section.name: ATTENDEE
section.t: The ATTENDEE property converts to a Participant object in the participants property. Its value converts to that Participant object's calendarAddress property.

figure.name: Example for converting the ATTENDEE property to JSCalendar

section.name: BUSYTYPE
section.t: The BUSYTYPE property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: CALENDAR-ADDRESS
section.t: The CALENDAR-ADDRESS property converts to a Participant object in the participants property. Its value converts to that Participant object's calendarAddress property.

figure.name: Example for converting the CALENDAR-ADDRESS property to JSCalendar

section.name: CALSCALE
section.t: The CALSCALE property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: CATEGORIES
section.t: The CATEGORIES property converts to the keywords property.

figure.name: Example for converting the CATEGORIES property to JSCalendar

section.name: CLASS
section.t: The CLASS property converts to the privacy property.

figure.name: Example for converting the CLASS property to JSCalendar

section.name: COLOR
section.t: The COLOR property converts to the color property.

figure.name: Example for converting the COLOR property to JSCalendar

section.name: COMMENT
section.t: The COMMENT property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: COMPLETED
section.t: The COMPLETED property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: CONCEPT
section.t: The CONCEPT property converts to the categories property.

figure.name: Example for converting the CONCEPT property to JSCalendar

section.name: CONFERENCE
section.t: The CONFERENCE property converts to a VirtualLocation object in the virtualLocations property. Its value converts to that VirtualLocation object's uri property.

figure.name: Example for converting the CONFERENCE property to JSCalendar

section.name: CONTACT
section.t: The CONTACT property converts to a Link object in the links property of an Event, Group or Task object, or Location object, or Participant object. Its value converts to that Link object's href property.

figure.name: Example for converting the CONTACT property to JSCalendar

section.name: CREATED
section.t: The CREATED property converts to the created property.

figure.name: Example for converting the CREATED property to JSCalendar

section.name: DESCRIPTION
section.t: The DESCRIPTION property converts to the TBDdescription.

figure.name: Example for converting the DESCRIPTION property to JSCalendar

section.name: DTEND
section.t: The DTEND property converts to the duration property of an Event object.

figure.name: Example for converting the DTEND property to JSCalendar

section.name: DTSTAMP
section.t: The DTSTAMP property converts to the updated property.

figure.name: Example for converting the DTSTAMP property to JSCalendar

section.name: DTSTART
section.t: The DTSTART property converts to the start property of a TimeZoneRule object.

figure.name: Example for converting the DTSTART property to JSCalendar

section.name: DUE
section.t: The DUE property converts to the due property of a Task object.

figure.name: Example for converting the DUE property to JSCalendar

section.name: DURATION
section.t: The DURATION property converts to the duration property of an Event object.

figure.name: Example for converting the DURATION property to JSCalendar

section.name: EXDATE
section.t: The EXDATE property converts to a PatchObject object in the recurrenceOverrides property of an Event or Task object, or TimeZoneRule object.
TBD .. Its value converts to that PatchObject object's excluded property.

figure.name: Example for converting the EXDATE property to JSCalendar

section.name: EXRULE
section.t: The EXRULE property converts to a RecurrenceRule object in the excludedRecurrenceRules property.

figure.name: Example for converting the EXRULE property to JSCalendar

section.name: FREEBUSY
section.t: The FREEBUSY property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: GEO
section.t: The GEO property converts to a Location object in the locations property. Its value converts to that Location object's coordinates property.

figure.name: Example for converting the GEO property to JSCalendar

section.name: IMAGE
section.t: The IMAGE property converts to a Link object in the links property of an Event, Group or Task object, or Location object, or Participant object. Its value converts to that Link object's href property.

figure.name: Example for converting the IMAGE property to JSCalendar

section.name: LAST-MODIFIED
section.t: The LAST-MODIFIED property converts to the updated property.

figure.name: Example for converting the LAST-MODIFIED property to JSCalendar

section.name: LINK
section.t: The LINK property converts to a Link object in the links property of an Event, Group or Task object, or Location object, or Participant object. Its value converts to that Link object's href property.

figure.name: Example for converting the LINK property to JSCalendar

section.name: LOCATION
section.t: The LOCATION property converts to a Location object in the locations property. Its value converts to that Location object's name property.

figure.name: Example for converting the LOCATION property to JSCalendar

section.name: LOCATION-TYPE
section.t: The LOCATION-TYPE property converts to the locationTypes property of a Location object.

figure.name: Example for converting the LOCATION-TYPE property to JSCalendar

section.name: METHOD
section.t: The METHOD property converts to the method property.

figure.name: Example for converting the METHOD property to JSCalendar

section.name: NAME
section.t: The NAME property in a VLOCATION component converts to a Location object in TBD... Its value converts to that Location object's TBDname.
The NAME property in a VCALENDAR component converts to a Group object in TBD... Its value converts to that Group object's title property.

figure.name: Example for converting the NAME property to JSCalendar

section.name: ORGANIZER
section.t: The ORGANIZER property converts to the replyTo property.

figure.name: Example for converting the ORGANIZER property to JSCalendar

section.name: PARTICIPANT-TYPE
section.t: The PARTICIPANT-TYPE property converts to the roles property of a Participant object.

section.t: The PERCENT-COMPLETE property converts to the percentComplete property.

figure.name: Example for converting the PERCENT-COMPLETE property to JSCalendar

section.t: The PRIORITY property converts to the priority property.

figure.name: Example for converting the PRIORITY property to JSCalendar

section.name: PRODID
section.t: The PRODID property converts to the prodId property.

figure.name: Example for converting the PRODID property to JSCalendar

section.name: PROXIMITY
section.t: The PROXIMITY property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: RDATE

section.t: The RECURRENCE-ID property converts to the recurrenceId property.

section.name: REFID
section.t: The REFID property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.t: The REFRESH-INTERVAL property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.t: The RELATED-TO property converts to a Relation object in the TBDrelatedTo.

figure.name: Example for converting the RELATED-TO property to JSCalendar

section.name: REPEAT
section.t: The REPEAT property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: REQUEST-STATUS
section.t: The REQUEST-STATUS property converts to TBD...

section.name: RESOURCE-TYPE
section.t: The RESOURCE-TYPE property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: RESOURCES
section.t: The RESOURCES property converts to a Participant object in the participants property. Its value converts to that Participant object's kind property.

figure.name: Example for converting the RESOURCES property to JSCalendar

section.name: RRULE
section.t: The RRULE property converts to a RecurrenceRule object in the recurrenceRules property of an Event or Task object, or TimeZoneRule object.

section.name: TZURL
section.t: The TZURL property converts to a TimeZone object in Its value converts to that TimeZone object's url property.

figure.name: Example for converting the TZURL property to JSCalendar

section.name: UID
section.t: The UID property converts to the uid property.

figure.name: Example for converting the UID property to JSCalendar

section.name: URL
section.t: The URL property converts to a Link object in the links property of an Event, Group or Task object, or Location object, or Participant object. Its value converts to that Link object's href property.

figure.name: Example for converting the URL property to JSCalendar

section.name: VERSION
section.t: The VERSION property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: XML
section.t: The XML property converts to a Link object in the links property of an Event, Group or Task object, or Location object, or Participant object. Its value converts to that Link object's href property.

figure.name: Example for converting the XML property to JSCalendar

dl.dd: This contains iCalendar components that are set in the iCalendar component represented by this JSCalendar object. The JCalComp type denotes a jCal-encoded iCalendar component as defined in .

figure.name: Example for the iCalComps property.
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR ... BEGIN:VEVENT SUMMARY:hello ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:X-COMPONENT UID:2EA10A8F-67FA-420F-8321-9C04F18AE60F SUMMARY:foo END:X-COMPONENT END:VCALENDAR

dl.dd: This contains iCalendar properties that are set in the iCalendar component represented by this JSCalendar object. The JCalProp type denotes a jCal-encoded iCalendar property as defined in .

figure.name: Example for the iCalProps property.
